meanings.definition: To change (something) in such a way as to lower its quality or value.
meanings.sent1: The chef bastardised the traditional recipe by adding too much salt.
meanings.sent2: The original painting was bastardised when someone painted over it with cheap colors.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked that his friend's attempt to cook a gourmet meal was bastardised by using instant noodles.
meanings.sent4: The once beautiful garden was bastardised by neglect and overgrowth.
meanings.sent5: The classic novel's plot was bastardised in the poorly made movie adaptation.

meanings.sent1: The politician's actions bastardised the trust of the people.
meanings.sent2: The company's unethical practices have bastardised their reputation in the industry.
meanings.sent3: The children's game of tag was bastardised when one player started tripping others on purpose.
meanings.sent4: The virus has bastardised the computer system, causing it to malfunction.
meanings.sent5: The once pure stream was bastardised by pollution from the factory.

meanings.sent1: The counterfeit products have bastardised the market, making it difficult to distinguish real from fake.
meanings.sent2: The addition of artificial flavors bastardised the taste of the homemade soup.
meanings.sent3: The student's attempt to copy the answers from a friend only bastardised their own understanding of the subject.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds bastardised the structure of the old barn.
meanings.sent5: The incorrect assembly instructions bastardised the final look of the furniture.
